FILE: cm235900v11.0.txt
DYAD: PORTUGAL - AUSTRALIA
RIVALRY: RIV651
DISPUTE(S): MID1066 

PS-LAST-CHANGED: 20180323
PS-LAST-CHECKED: 20180323

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

WWII MIDs: MID1066


RIVNOTES: 


NARRATIVE-CM:
Portugal and Indonesia have disputed the status of East Timor since Indonesia's invasion of the territory on December 7, 1975. The *Revolutionary Front for Independence* (FRETILIN) had declared East Timor's independence from Portugal on November 28, 1975, but the Indonesian government opposed the independence of East Timor. Portugal severed diplomatic relations with Indonesia, and referred the matter to the *United Nations Security Council (UNSC) on December 8, 1975. The *World Council of Churches *(WCC) appealed for peaceful negotiations on December 10, 1975. The *United Nations *(UN) General Assembly approved a resolution on December 12, 1975, condemning the Indonesian invasion and demanding the withdrawal of Indonesian troops from East Timor. The UN Security Council approved resolutions on December 22, 1975 and April 22, 1976, which demanded the withdrawal of Indonesian troops from East Timor. Indonesia announced on August 27, 1976 that East Timor had become the 27th province of Indonesia. The UN General Assembly approved a resolution on December 1, 1976, which called on Indonesia to withdraw its troops from East Timor. Australia recognized Indonesia's sovereignty over East Timor on January 20, 1978. New Zealand expressed support for Indonesia on the issue of East Timor on July 20, 1978. Portugal proposed bilateral negotiations with Indonesia on September 13, 1980, but Indonesia rejected the proposal on September 21, 1980. The UN secretary-general facilitated bilateral negotiations between Indonesian and Portuguese representatives beginning in July 1983. Jamsheed Marker of Pakistan was appointed as personal representative of the UN secretary-general for East Timor on February 12, 1997. Portugal and Indonesia signed an agreement in New York on May 5, 1999, which provided for a referendum on East Timorese autonomy within Indonesia. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan announced the establishment of the *United Nations Mission in East Timor* (UNAMET) on May 24, 1999, and UNAMET opened an office in Dili on June 3, 1999. UNAMET consisted of 460 civilian police personnel and 300 military liaison personnel headed by Ian Martin of Britain. The UN Security Council authorized UNAMET on June 11, 1999. Alan Mills of Australia was appointed head of the UNAMET civlian police mission on June 14, 1999, and UN civilian police arrived in East Timor beginning on June 21, 1999. The referendum was held in East Timor on August 30, 1999, and some 79 percent of the voters rejected autonomy within Indonesia. The *International Federation for East Timor-Observer Project *(IFET-OP), which consisted of some 120 observers from 16 countries, monitored the referendum process from June 22 to September 4, 1999. The *Asian Network for Free Elections (ANFREL) sent 42 election observers to monitor the referendum. The *Carter Center* (CC) sent 20 observers to monitor the referendum from July 9 to September 4, 1999. The *Australia East Timor International Volunteers Project* (AETIVP) sent 30 observers to monitor the referendum. *Amnesty International* condemned Indonesia on September 4, 1999 for failing to prevent widespread violence in East Timor during the pre-referendum and post-referendum periods. *European Union* (EU) foreign ministers imposed military sanctions (arms embargo) against Indonesia on September 14, 1999. The UN Security Council authorized an international peacekeeping force for East Timor on September 15, 1999. Indonesia and Portugal resumed diplomatic relations on December 28, 1999.

SOURCES-CM: 
Allock et al., 1992, 488-497; *Associated Press,* September 4, 1999, December 28, 1999; Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 210-212; *Kyodo News Service*, August 17, 1999, September 4, 1999, September 14, 1999, September 15, 1999, December 28, 1999; *Reuters*, May 5, 1999, May 7, 1999, September 4, 1999; Weisburd, 1997, 247-251.



NARRATIVE-CR:
